Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: SaTC: TTP: Medium: NextGenPQ: Post-quantum Schemes for Next Generation Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The proliferation of advances in quantum computing has put traditional cryptography and our entire computing and communications infrastructure in danger. The threat is so urgent that the US National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) started a standardization competition in 2018 to select one or more so-called Post-Quantum (PQ) schemes. Traditional cryptographic techniques are expected to be replaced by PQ-schemes in applications during the next decade. Unfortunately, the upgrade comes at a cost since PQ-schemes require significant increases in digital signature and public key sizes. The team of researchers tackle this very problem. The project's novelties are new techniques to enable aggregation of PQ signatures. The project's impacts are reduced energy consumption and spectrum efficiency in applications such as sensor networks, 5G systems, IoT devices, and Blockchains.<br/><br/>The investigation is structured in two research modules. The first module focuses on developing aggregation extensions to existing PQ signature algorithms. The work in this module includes a thorough security analysis of the extensions, and selection of parameters for secure and efficient construction. The second module investigates new PQ signature schemes that allow more efficient aggregation. This module will build on the recent works on homomorphic signature schemes. The security and performance of the developed signature schemes will be scrutinized and compared to existing schemes.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The emergence of quantum computers imposes a threat on currently deployed cryptosystems. To address this issue the United States National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) has developed new standards to replace traditional cryptography with newly emerging cryptosysyems referred to as post-quantum (PQ) schemes across our computing infrastructure.


This project investigated the security and efficiency of next generation cryptographic schemes for  desirable extended features such as the ability to compress keys as well as to aggregate multiple signatures, to compress thousands or millions of signatures into one short one while retaining verifiability.


Project Year 1 activities included a review of NIST Round 3 PQ signature scheme submissions. The team reviewed the Dilithium and Facon Signature Schemes with the goal of finding a way to define aggregation extensions similar to those used in an earlier scheme called MMSAT proposed by the team members. Unlike MMSAT, the NIST Submissions were found to be not amenable for implementation of extensions due to extensive customizations included in the schemes. The team further investigated MMSAT signature aggregation extension for efficiency and security. Specifically, the parameter sets were updated based on our latest security analysis and feedback from practicioners in the area.

 In addition to signature schemes, another class of primitives important for applications, e.g. in Blockchains, is verifiable random functions and verifiable delay functions. These primitives allow a node to generate randomness/or introduce fixed delay in a way that is publicly and efficiently verifiable by the other nodes. For instance, these functions allow nodes in a Blockchain to syncrhonize more efficiently. The team developed a number of candidate lattice verifiable function schemes with potential for quantum security with security reductions left for future work.

In project Year 2 the team continued to work on the MMSAT signature aggregation extension. A vulnerability in MMSAT was discovered by a Japanese resercher. In collaboration with researchers from France and Australia the project team analyzed a number of possible modifications to the MMSAT scheme to mitigate the vulnerability. These exchanges significantly improved our understanding of the security requirements of aggregation schemes.

The team had also earlier proposed a new homomorphic encryption scheme based on the hardness of the finite field inversion (FFI) problem conjectured to be hard. The FFI problem was used to build a new signature scheme. The project team investigated the possibility of compressions of many signatures into one for FFI based signature schemes. During this work the team became aware of a newly discovered attack by a French cryptohrapher that directly challenges the hardness of the FFI problem.

Further in Project Year 2 during the review of lattice based NIST finalist post-quantum schemes of Dilithium and Falcon, the researchers found a new vulnerability that takes advantage of software faults which is then when mathematically analyzed yields to full recovery of the key. The technique was named Signature Correction Attack (SCA). The team demonstrated with a practical implementation that this attack it is indeed possible for reastically attacking Dilithium with current key sizes. Dilithium is one of the schemes chosen by NIST to replace the old digital signature standard across our instrastructure. The results of this attack were shared with the greater research community with workshop presentations. This work also motivated some newer PQ proposals to implement fault checking as a countermeasure.

The project was extended for a another year to give time for the staff to complete their research work. The investigation studied another target scheme, Falcon, selected by NIST for a similar a signature correction attack. While partial recovery is possible, a full key recovery appears to be harder due to the way Falcon is implementated suggesting a new mitigation strategy. The team noticed that the Signature Correction Attack, discovered while studying PQ schemes, could also be adapted to work with traditional signature schemes such as such as RSA, DSA and ECDSA. These cryptographic schemes currently make up the cryptographic backbone of our the computing and communications infrastructure. The team analyzed a number popular cryptgraphic libraries used in millions of computers randing from personal computers to cloud servers, and determined indeed they were vulnerable to the same attack. The team filed vulnerability disclosured and worked with libary vendors to develop, test and deploy security patches.

Beyond the research findings, the project provided a perfect opportunity for the training of the next generation security professionals. The project partially funded the studies of several doctoral and masters students, among which two were from underreprested groups. The project supported two doctoral dissertations and one masters thesis. Findings and experiences gained from the project, especially regarding of the type of new cryptography resilient against quantum computers, was not only shared with fellow researchers and industry participants, but also made it into graduate level courses offered at the institute.
